definitions.definition: to manage and organize the affairs of a company, an organization, a country, etc.

examples.text: the high cost of administering medical services
The pension funds are administered by commercial banks.
The charity is administered by a 20-strong management committee.
The country has to face up to the high cost of administering medical services.

definitions.definition: to make sure that something is done fairly and in the correct way

examples.text: The questionnaire was administered by trained interviewers.
It is the function of the courts to administer the laws which Parliament has enacted.
Bishops came before the Pope and justice was administered by him in person.
The team is responsible for administering the tests and marking the papers.

definitions.definition: to give or to provide something, especially in a formal way

examples.text: The teacher has the authority to administer punishment.
A taxi driver administered first aid to the victims.
The priest was called to administer the last rites.

definitions.definition: to give drugs, medicine, etc. to somebody

examples.text: Police believe his wife could not have administered the poison.
The dose was administered to the child intravenously.

definitions.definition: to kick or to hit somebody/something
definitions.sensetop: administer a kick, a punch, etc. (to somebody/something)

examples.text: He administered a severe blow to his opponent's head.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin administrare, from ad- ‘to’ + ministrare ‘wait upon’, from minister ‘servant’, from minus ‘less’.
